text: Patient: Okay. Now, so, along with what we’ve talked about, if we decide that, uh, uh, the, uh, the clinical trial is not working- Doctor: Um hum. Patient: Then, what I’m going to do is go back to K___? And so J___ H___ will not be involved anymore after that? Doctor: So let’s talk about that for a second. So there are two main options. One is that if you wanted to pursue a standard therapy, such as enzalutamide, also called Xtandi, or chemotherapy, that would be through K___, because as a standard therapy, you will not have privileges, unless you paid out of pocket, to come here for that therapy. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: On the other hand, the second possibility is to participate in a different clinical trial. So I’ll give you one example. So we have a trial right now testing immunotherapy against prostate cancer. That is a drug that stimulates your own immune system to hopefully fight and kill the cancer. Okay? That’s just one example. We might have at least one more trial that you’re also eligible for. But both of these trials would not really rely on that mutation, specifically, but they are just trials that you would still qualify for, uh, independent of the mutation. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: If you decided to participate in a different clinical trial, then, of course, you could receive that therapy here as long as K___ approved of you to enroll in that trial, which they probably will, because their general policy is if you’re participating in a trial at an institution that’s not available through K___, then they support that. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So you could definitely still be our patient, and we would love it if you were. Uh, we’ve gotten to know you for the past several months, and I think your experience with us has also been relatively good. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, so, you know, that could be a win-win, but we have to make sure that it’s something that makes sense for you. We’re not going to put you on a trial just for the sake of keeping you at H___.

text: Patient: I’m sorry, it also mentioned that Metformin is a cancer fighter. Doctor: Right, there is some evidence which I would call modest. You know in other words it’s not absolutely conclusive, but it’s not you know terribly weak either um that , at prostate cancer specifically, and other cancers in general, there might be a direct anti tumor effect Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: Now uhm I am somewhat convinced by the data. Uhm the perfect way to prove that, and this may never happen, is to actually design a trial. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Where you take people that already have a diagnosis of prostate cancer – Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: - and then you randomize it. In other words, you flip a coin. You give half of them a specified dose of Metformin and you give the other half a placebo immunotherapy. Patient: Right. Doctor: And then at the end of the day you look at the outcomes and you see are the recurrence rates you know slowed down less in the patients that receive the Metformin or alternatively our prevention rates that with time those that don’t receive the Metformin. The - the type of studies that have suggested that Metformin is beneficial, the so-called epidemiological studies. In other words, given the retrospectives, where they take a series of patients – Patient: Got it. Doctor: - and they go back and ask them based on questionnaires Were you taking Metformin and when did you start and how long? What was the reason for being on it? Patient: Yes.

text: Family Member: Is that what they did to him before when he went down there? They - Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: Where the pain, where the pain was? Doctor: Uh hum, well there, they radiated you from the outside. You laid down and they beamed it to you, right. This is internal. So when they push it in your bloodstream it goes all around and it lands in the area of the bone that has the cancer. Family Member: Is there side effects? Doctor: Oh yeah, there’s always side effects. Because it’s radiation, some of the side effects could be you know reduced or lower amounts of blood cells in your system, so people could get low white cells, red cells, platelets. Those are your three guys that I always watch out for and in some people, it’s a pretty big dip and you don’t come back. Very rare, but it’s a possibility. Family Member: What do you mean a dip? Doctor: Meaning it destroys too much. Family Member: Oh. Doctor: And there’s no coming back. But you know in terms of how much does that occur, it’s very rare. Could it occur—sure, and I tend to see it in folks who have had a lot of therapy, especially chemo. You’ve had pills and more pills, a little smattering of radiation and a Provenge, and a partridge in a pear tree. So where you are coming in is your bone marrow is not as compromised as a person who had chemo. I’m not saying that you couldn’t get it after chemo, but the perfect person to give it in is a person who is actually having some pain, which you are, a person that otherwise is in good shape, and has a good enough bone marrow reserve, which you do, and it’s not related to any other treatment like steroids and things like that, where if I were to offer chemo, that would be part of the package. Again, not impossible for us to go down the chemo route, but that’s also the next discussion. But for this, I think it’s reasonable to talk to the radiation doctor about it because you’ll want to know pros and cons. So the bone marrow is the thing I always worry about, but for my other patients, and I’ve had many go through it, the other part that it could affect would be your gut. So diarrhea, stomach upset, not so much nausea and vomiting but just more like you know you’ve got the poops kind of thing. But for you it’s obviously something we could regulate because you could get Imodium, you know. You could get treatment. A lot of my patients have it during the time around you know the week that you get injected and then nothing else. So that’s kind of where it is. Oh, and if you have cancer that’s not in the bone, like liver or lungs, which you don’t have, but those patients, they don’t; you know they shouldn’t be treated with this medicine because that medicine that I’m thinking about for you is only for bone. So it will not go to liver or anywhere else. Family Member: So the pain that he’s having - Doctor: Is in bone. Family Member: And how big of a spot does he have there – on his hip and lower leg, upper leg.

text: Family Member: So how long is this? I mean once we starts it. What will they do? Doctor: So you come back every month, and we’ll see you initially- you report any side effects. And the way that this usually works is that well, for any treatment, we continue the treatment until either disease progression, meaning that your disease is getting worse despite the treatments of the treatments not working anymore, or unacceptable toxicity. So if you have really bad side effects, we're not going to continue the treatment. Patient: Right. Doctor: So this Yeah, so this one is talking about your risks of discomfort. The most common one is gassiness. So you might not be the most pleasant person to be around while you're taking this, but that's, I mean, it's only 8%. So it's not really that common, but most people usually do fine there. Been no serious side effects. So, you know, it's very safe for us it doesn't cost anything there are no extra costs it's just what would be done in normal clinical care anyways is what they've done anything that would be extra that's like not covered by insurance like this blood test, to check your genotype it’s covered by the study. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: You don't get paid to join the study, you can leave at any time to protect your privacy, you do tend to get parking tickets, so that like you know, when you come visits okay and then these are the this is the contact information for our clinic. Family Member: So it’s a monthly, a monthly thing? Doctor: So the treatment you actually take every single day, so, the pills, so what you what you do usually is that you come in, we make sure that you're taking you after usually fill out a drug diary so that we see how many like if you're missing days, you take the pills, and then we would give you refills of the pills. Family Member: Okay, so will there be a blood test when he comes back also? Doctor: Yeah. Not every single time. Family Member: oh OKAY. And how long is this trial for? Doctor: This one, I think it's for two years so that you can, you can stay on it. You can stay on it for two years. Usually, if people are getting benefit, and they're still on it, then usually we can work with the company to continue it. Even though technically the study ends. But that's not always the case. Technically. I mean, usually, that's not always the case.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
